awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Persistent measurements of surface waves in landfast ice using fiber optic telecommunication cables
awd_abstract_narration:
In shallow, coastal regions of the Arctic, sea ice forming on the ocean that is attached to the coast is known as landfast ice. Breakup of this ice is likely driven by a combination of melting and ocean wave action. Following spring breakup, when ice is not present for the summer months, there is more wave energy at the coast. Waves can increase coastal erosion. However, our understanding of the processes by which waves break up coastal sea ice and contribute to Arctic coastal erosion are still limited by a lack of observations. This project will test use of a new technology for better measuring waves in coastal ice. The success of this project will significantly advance our ability to understand the rapidly eroding coastal Arctic. The results will have broad applications for both scientific and coastal Arctic communities, and the project will engage local high school students to build and deploy instruments.

This project will test our ability to measure waves in ice-covered regions using seafloor cables. The investigators will measure waves along a seafloor cable and by surface buoys over week-long periods in spring, summer, and fall 2022. Cable measurements will be collected using shore-based instrumentation by collaborators at Sandia National Laboratory, while buoys will be deployed along the length of the cable by airborne or vessel-based methods. These measurements aim to address fundamental questions about coastal ice and its breakup, including: (1) What is the role of waves in breaking up ice? and (2) How do waves change and evolve in areas of coastal ice? The co-location of buoy deployments and cable measurements during this period aims to produce a method that will allow researchers to measure waves using seafloor cables in the future with no additional deployment of equipment. The potential for persistent, high-resolution observations of surface waves using cables opens new avenues of research in this area. The ice-covered season in the Alaskan Arctic is expected to continue to shorten in future years, and the role of waves is likely to be greater. This project will begin building networks to use this technology to answer societally relevant questions, through Arctic science networks and in local communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) of seafloor fiber optic cables is a novel method for oceanographic measurements in coastal oceans. With this method, the scattering of laser pulses off impurities in the glass fiber provides a measurement of the fiber strain-rate, which responds to a variety of phenomena including the hydrostatic pressure of the surface wave field. The strain-rate can be measured at spacing down to the order of meters along tens of kilometers of fiber. This method can provide substantial advantages in measuring ocean surface wave fields in seasonally ice-covered coastal Arctic.  The specific advantages are: (1) waves can be observed continuously with unprecedentedly high spatial resolution over long distances, and (2) these measurements can be made with no or minimal additional oceanographic deployment. 

 

The project “Persistent measurements of surface waves in landfast ice using fiber optic telecommunication cables” was funded as collaborative research between the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and University of Washington for two years through an EAGER award in NSF’s Office of Polar Programs Arctic Natural Sciences. The primary outcomes of this project include (1) the first quantitative surface wave measurements using seafloor distributed acoustic sensing with an empirical calibration, and (2) the most highly spatially-resolved estimates of surface wave attenuation in new landfast ice demonstrating rapid co-evolution of the wave and ice fields.

 

The observational program focused on DAS measurements made in 2022 and 2023 on a seafloor telecommunication cable from Oliktok Point, Alaska, which were compared with wave observations made with more common methods. In 2022, a total of 14 small wave buoys (microSWIFTs) were deployed aerially and 1 moored wave buoy was deployed by ship along the cable route. In 2023, 3 seafloor pressure moorings were deployed from April-September along the cable. The 2022 mooring data was used to provide an empirical calibration of the DAS observations, such that waves could be calculated along most of the cable. This method results in a high correlation with buoy observations. In the coastal Arctic, we observe that the rapid evolution of the location and strength of wave attenuation can serve as a proxy for the evolution of landfast ice. 

 

With the robust demonstration of the applicability of this method in a broad range of environments, this technology can be applied to understanding diverse coastal questions. Inter-comparison of this and other coastal DAS datasets is providing the knowledge needed for the broader scientific community to apply this technology more widely. Future work in the coastal Arctic and other regions will further leverage DAS to understand the role of waves in important coastal processes. 

 

The project included a multi-year collaboration with a local school in Kaktovik, Alaska, sharing information on “Arctic Coastal Oceanography”, and culminating in the local deployment of simple wave buoys and moorings built by the students. The classroom and hands-on lessons developed through this effort have been archived on the “Teach the Earth” portal for future implementation in this school and elsewhere. The scientists additionally participated in recording of an episode of the podcast “Arctic Science Sessions” on both the scientific and outreach efforts. Finally, this project provided data that was used in training of both an undergraduate and graduate student, and supported the development of an early-career scientist.
